Award.AwardTitle: CC*DNI Network Infrastructure: The Gopher Science Network - A Dedicated Science Network for the University of Minnesota

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
The University of Minnesota (UMN) is building a dedicated campus research network (Gopher Science Network or GSN) to connect its world-class physical and intellectual resources with its state, regional, national and global research and education partners. The new network connectivity accelerates the transition of the UMN campus from an enclave within which research is conducted to the nerve center of a widespread, interactive research ecosystem: less an ivory tower than an organic web. On a national scale, the GSN not only benefits NSF-funded research, but also strengthens existing partnerships with other agencies (e.g. NASA, NIH, DOE, DOD, USGS) and universities nationwide by facilitating bidirectional access to facilities, data, and intellectual resources.

The GSN bridges high speed links to Minnesota's regional optical network with a dedicated 100 Gbps campus research network linking two NSF funded centers located on UMN Twin Cities campus, several core campus research facilities, and advanced research in dynamic networks and high performance computing. The GSN is accelerating discoveries in genomics, proteomics, advanced networking, high resolution satellite imagery, demographics, magnetic resonance, and advanced computational research and infrastructures by removing the network as a barrier to advanced data intensive research and complex analysis workflows. With a governance structure that encourages broad participation from researchers, educators, and central IT specialists, UMN is able to magnify the broader impacts efforts of research and education projects that use the GSN.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The University of Minnesota successfully created the Gopher Science Network (GSN), a dedicated high-performance research network. This network links seven buildings on campus at dual 100Gbps, provides a separate 100Gbps uplink to the research and education network (Internet 2), and continues to grow as other researchers become aware of the capabilities offered by the GSN. Some of the new participants into the network include the campus imaging facilities as well as new faculty research spaces. In addition to a physical network, the increased cyberinfrastructure led to holistic thinking of ways to meet and improve research needs. Globus has become a key data transfer tool deployed campuswide with very high rates of adoption and building new capabilities. Increased access to network resources allows researchers to consider cloud options for data archiving and compute, moving over 500TB to Google, reducing the burden to local researchers. Cybersecurity was not originally in the scope of the GSN but became a critical factor as the network was deployed. This led to deep discussions and an architecture redesign of the network before the network could be used.

Outreach activities included hosting a regional cyberinfrastructure workshop in 2017 with 28 attendees, and helping two regional institutions compete for CC* grants in 2018. This knowledge transfer includes network and security design guidance and lessons learned.

The GSN provided the networking capacity needed to complete the NSF ArcticDEM and the Reference Elevation Model of Antarctica (REMA) projects (NSF Awards #1559691, 1543501, 1614673, 1810976). The computing was performed at NCSA Blue Waters and required over 3.8 PB of data transferred over three years. The result of ArcticDEM and REMA was to create high-resolution digital elevation models of both poles that can be used by researchers to study such activities as ice movement and surface process. ArcticDEM covers ~160M km2 (https://www.pgc.umn.edu/data/arcticdem/) and REMA covers ~120M km2 (https://www.pgc.umn.edu/data/rema/)..
